habitat_description:
Northeast:
New England cottontails inhabit a wide variety of environments but prefer boreal habitat types containing eracacious plants such as mountain laurel (Kalmia), blueberry (Vaccinium), and an overstory of conifer and hardwoods. Forage includes grasses and clover during spring/summer and shrub twigs in winter (Wilson and Ruff 1999). In general, habitats tend to be dense, bushy woodlands including those adjacent and within spruce-pine forest, salt marsh, oak forest, and open upland fields (Godin 1977). Understory cover is a key component of habitat (Smith and Litvaitis 2000, Chapman and Litvaitis 2003) especially in confierous habitats (Litvaitis et al. 1985). Most of the time this species is reluctant to venture more than 5 meters from suitable cover (Barbour and Litvaitis 1993).
